description: The screenshot displays a standard Windows XP desktop. The taskbar, located at the bottom of the screen, shows the "Start" button on the left corner. Next to the "Start" button, an inactive area spans the taskbar. The right side of the taskbar displays system icons, including network connectivity, speaker volume, and the system clock showing the time as 10:56 AM. The "Recycle Bin" icon is visible on the desktop.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop with the "Start" menu open. The "Start" menu displays a list of programs and options. The taskbar is still visible at the bottom, displaying the "Start" button, an inactive area, system icons, and the system clock showing 10:56 AM. The "Recycle Bin" icon remains visible on the desktop. 
- New UI Elements: The "Start" menu is now visible. It appears as a pop-up window over the desktop, originating from the "Start" button on the taskbar. 
- Missing UI Elements:  None.
- Content Changes: None.
The screenshot displays the Windows XP desktop with the "Start" menu open. The "Control Panel" option is highlighted, indicating the user's mouse is hovering over it.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Start Menu open with the mouse cursor hovering over the "Control Panel" option. A yellow tooltip box provides a description: "Provides options for you to customize the appearance and functionality of your computer, add or remove programs, and set up network connections and user accounts."
The screenshot shows the Windows XP Start Menu open. The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Control Panel" option, and the yellow tooltip box with the description is gone.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop with the Start Menu open. The "Control Panel" option is highlighted, but the yellow tooltip box is no longer visible.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop background, which features a tropical beach scene. The Start Menu is visible in its closed state. The mouse cursor, displaying an hourglass icon, is positioned in the top center of the screen. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The Start Menu is no longer open.
- The yellow tooltip box describing the Control Panel is not present.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop with a tropical beach scene as the wallpaper. The "Start" button is visible in the bottom left corner. The "Recycle Bin" icon is present on the desktop. The mouse cursor is not hovering over any active window or menu. 

The Start Menu and the yellow tooltip box describing the Control Panel are no longer visible.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop background, featuring a tropical beach scene. The "Control Panel" window, previously described as open, is no longer visible. The Start Menu is also no longer visible.

The screenshot shows an open window titled "Control Panel" against a grey background. The window only contains a folder icon labeled "Control Panel" in the top left corner. The Windows XP Start Menu is visible at the bottom of the screen. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Control Panel" option in the Start Menu.
- The yellow tooltip box describing the Control Panel is no longer visible.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel window in "Category View". The previously open Start Menu is no longer visible. The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Control Panel" option and the yellow tooltip box is gone.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel window open. The window displays a variety of icons, each representing a different category of system settings. These categories include "Appearance and Themes," "Network and Internet Connections," "Add or Remove Programs," "Sounds, Speech, and Audio Devices," "Performance and Maintenance," "Printers and Other Hardware," "User Accounts," "Date, Time, Language, and Regional Options," "Accessibility Options," and "Security Center."

Missing UI Elements:
- The Start Menu is no longer visible.
- The mouse cursor and its yellow tooltip box are no longer present.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel window in "Category View". The previously open Start Menu is no longer visible. The yellow tooltip box is also absent from the screenshot.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel window open and in front of the Start Menu. The Control Panel displays various category icons like "Appearance and Themes", "Network and Internet Connections", and "Add or Remove Programs". 

The yellow tooltip box previously visible is no longer present.
The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel window in "Category View". The previously open Start Menu is no longer visible. The mouse cursor is not visible.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel window open and active. The yellow tooltip box is no longer visible.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel window in "Category View". The mouse cursor is now hovering over the "Network and Internet Connections" icon.  The yellow tooltip box that was previously visible is no longer present.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category view. The mouse cursor hovers over the "Appearance and Themes" category. This category allows users to modify the visual aspects of their desktop environment, such as applying themes, changing the screen saver, and customizing the Start menu and taskbar.  A text box providing further information about the category's function is also displayed.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel in Category view. The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Appearance and Themes" category. The text box that was providing further information about the category's function is no longer displayed.

The screenshot displays an empty Windows XP Control Panel window.  The mouse cursor has moved from hovering over the "Appearance and Themes" category to the center of the empty window. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Appearance and Themes" category and its associated text box are no longer visible.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category view. The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Appearance and Themes" category. The text box providing further information about the category's function is no longer displayed.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel, specifically the "Appearance and Themes" category, with the mouse cursor hovering over the "Choose a screen saver" task. The text box providing further information about the category's function is no longer visible.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel in Category view. The "Appearance and Themes" category is selected, and the mouse cursor is hovering over the "Choose a screen saver" task. The text box providing further information about the category's function is still visible.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category view. The "Appearance and Themes" category is selected, and the "Choose a screen saver" task is highlighted with the mouse cursor hovering over it.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category view. The "Appearance and Themes" category is selected, and the mouse cursor is hovering over the "Choose a screen saver" task.

The screenshot shows the Windows XP Control Panel in Category view. The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Appearance and Themes" category. The text box providing further information about the category's function is also gone.

The screenshot displays the Windows XP Control Panel in Category view. The "Appearance and Themes" category is selected, and the mouse cursor is hovering over the "Choose a screen saver" task. The text box below the category title provides a list of tasks related to appearance and themes, such as changing the computer's theme, desktop background, screen resolution, and screen saver.  There are no new UI elements, missing UI elements, or content changes.

The screenshot displays the "Appearance and Themes" window within the Windows XP Control Panel. The user has navigated to this window, as indicated by the open folder icon in the taskbar. The mouse cursor is hovering over the "Display" icon, suggesting the user is about to interact with it.

The screenshot shows the "Appearance and Themes" window in the Windows XP Control Panel.  The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Display" icon. The taskbar now shows that the "Appearance and The..." window is currently active.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window with a white background, indicating an active window. However, it does not display any of the tabs or settings that are typically found within the "Display Properties" window. Instead, an hourglass cursor is visible in the center of the window, suggesting that the system is busy or an operation is in progress. 

The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Display" icon as described in the initial state.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in the foreground.  A smaller "Active Window" dialog box is now open on top of the "Display Properties" window. The dialog box features minimize, maximize, and close buttons in the top right corner. The mouse cursor, now displaying an hourglass icon, is hovering within this smaller dialog box.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in the "Themes" tab.  The "Appearance and Themes" window from the initial description is no longer present. The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Display" icon.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window with the "Themes" tab active.  The mouse cursor is no longer hovering over the "Display" icon. A small window titled "Active Window" is now visible, positioned over the sample wallpaper image within the "Display Properties" window.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in the Windows XP Control Panel, specifically the "Themes" tab. 

At the top, we see the following tabs:
- **Themes:** Currently selected, indicating the user is modifying visual and audio settings applied to the system.
- **Desktop:** Allows customization of the desktop background image.
- **Screen Saver:** Allows configuration of the screen saver settings.
- **Appearance:** Provides options to customize the appearance of windows, buttons, and other system elements.
- **Settings:**  Allows adjustment of screen resolution, color quality, and other display settings.

The "Themes" tab itself displays the following:
- **Theme:** A dropdown menu to select a pre-configured theme, currently displaying "Windows XP (Modified)". This suggests the user has made changes to the default theme.
- **Save As...:** A button to save the current theme settings under a new name, allowing for custom themes.
- **Delete:** A button to delete the currently selected theme (only available for custom themes).
- **Sample:** A preview window displaying the current theme's desktop background, showcasing a tropical beach scene. 

At the bottom of the "Display Properties" window, we see three buttons:
- **OK:** Confirms the current settings and closes the window.
- **Cancel:** Discards any changes made and closes the window.
- **Apply:** Applies the current settings without closing the window. 

This screenshot captures the state before any changes are confirmed or discarded, as both the "OK" and "Cancel" buttons are active.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window, with the "Screen Saver" tab now selected instead of the "Themes" tab. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Theme" dropdown menu, "Save As..." button, "Delete" button, and the "Sample" preview window are no longer present.

New UI Elements: 
- A large preview area depicting a computer monitor now occupies the majority of the window.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in the Windows XP Control Panel. The "Screen Saver" tab is now selected. The preview window displays a black screen with the text "Windows XP" in the center. The "Windows XP" screensaver is selected in the dropdown menu.  The tropical beach scene from the "Themes" tab is no longer visible.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window, with the "Screen Saver" tab now selected instead of the "Themes" tab. 

The "Sample:" preview window now displays a black screen with the text "Windows XP" in the center. 

The following elements are present, which were not in the initial description:
- **Screen saver:** A dropdown menu to select the desired screensaver, currently displaying "Windows XP".
- **Settings:** A button that presumably allows customization of the selected screensaver.
- **Preview:** A button that presumably triggers a preview of the selected screensaver.
- **Wait:** A numerical input field followed by "minutes", likely used to set the delay before the screensaver activates. The value in the field is "10".
- **On resume, password protect:** A checkbox that is currently unchecked.
- **Monitor power:** A text label with instructions to adjust monitor power settings.
- **Power...**: A button to access monitor power settings. 

The following elements are no longer present:
- **Theme:** The dropdown menu to select a pre-configured theme.
- **Save As...:** The button to save custom themes.
- **Delete:** The button to delete custom themes.

The screenshot displays the "Screen Saver" tab of the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP. 

The "Screen saver" dropdown menu currently displays "Windows XP", indicating the selected screensaver. The user can click the dropdown arrow to choose from a list of available screensavers. 

Below, the "Wait" field displays "10" with up and down arrows, allowing the user to set the idle time in minutes before the screensaver activates. This field is active, meaning the user can click the arrows or directly type in a desired duration.

The "On resume, password protect" checkbox is currently unchecked. If enabled, this option would require the user to re-enter their password after the screensaver activates.

The "Monitor power" section provides a brief instruction: "To adjust monitor power settings and save energy, click Power."  This section highlights the "Power..." button, which, when clicked, opens the "Power Options Properties" window for further power management configurations.

At the bottom of the window, the standard "OK", "Cancel", and "Apply" buttons are visible. These buttons allow the user to apply the selected settings, discard changes, or close the window respectively.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window open with the "Screen Saver" tab selected. The dropdown menu, used for selecting a screensaver, is expanded, revealing a list of available screensavers. 
- The "None" option within the "Screen saver" dropdown menu is highlighted, indicating it has been selected.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window open on the "Screen Saver" tab. The most noticeable change is that the "Screen saver" dropdown menu is expanded, displaying a list of available screensavers. The option "[None]" is highlighted within this list, but "Windows XP" is still displayed as the currently selected screensaver.

The screenshot displays the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. 

The "Screen Saver" dropdown menu is open, showing a list of available screen savers. The option "None" is currently highlighted, indicating it's selected as the active screen saver. 

To the right of the dropdown menu are three buttons:
- **Settings:** Currently greyed out, indicating it's inactive due to "None" being selected.
- **Preview:** Also greyed out for the same reason as "Settings."
- **Power...:** This button allows access to advanced power settings and management options. 
 
At the bottom of the window, two standard buttons are visible:
- **Apply:**  Currently active and clickable, allowing the user to apply the selected screen saver setting ("None").
- **Cancel:**  Allows the user to discard any changes and close the window.
The screenshot shows the Windows XP desktop. The "Display Properties" window is no longer present. The "Appearance and Themes" window is minimized to the taskbar, visible at the bottom of the screen.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. The "Screen Saver" dropdown menu is closed. The "Settings" and "Preview" buttons are still greyed out. 

The most noticeable difference is that the "Wait" time is now set to "10" minutes. The checkbox for "On resume, password protect" is unchecked.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. 

The "Screen saver" dropdown menu is set to "[None]". Below, a text box labeled "Wait:" allows numerical input in minutes, currently set to "10", to define the idle time before the screen saver activates. A checkbox labeled "On resume, password protect" is unchecked. 

The user's mouse cursor hovers over the "Power" button located within the "Monitor power" section. This section also contains a brief instruction: "To adjust monitor power settings and save energy, click Power." 

At the bottom of the window, standard buttons "OK", "Cancel", and "Apply" are visible.

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window overlaid on the "Display Properties" window. 

New UI Elements:
- The "Power Options Properties" window is now visible. This window features:
    - A title bar with the title "Power Options Properties" and standard window controls.
    - An informational message: "Select the power scheme with the most appropriate settings for this computer. Note that changing the settings below will modify the selected scheme."
    - A "Power schemes" dropdown menu, currently displaying "Home/Office Desk".
    - Buttons labeled "Save As..." and "Delete".
    - A section titled "Settings for Home/Office Desk power scheme", containing:
        - The label "Turn off monitor:".
        - A dropdown menu next to "Turn off monitor:", currently set to "After 20 mins".
        - The label "Turn off hard disks:".
        - A dropdown menu next to "Turn off hard disks:", also containing options for time intervals.

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Screen Saver" tab content from the "Display Properties" window is no longer visible. 
- The mouse cursor is no longer present.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Power Schemes" tab in focus. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Display Properties" window is no longer present.

New UI Elements:
- The "Power Options Properties" window is now visible, with the "Power Schemes" tab selected. 

Content Changes:
- The mouse cursor is now hovering over the dropdown menu associated with "System hibernates:".

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP.  

The active window "Power Options Properties" allows users to manage their computer's power consumption settings. 

**Key Elements:**

* **Power Schemes:** The "Home/Office Desk" scheme is currently selected in the dropdown menu. This menu would allow the user to choose from pre-set or custom power plans. 
* **"Save As" button:**  This button allows the user to save the current settings as a new power scheme.
* **"Delete" button:** This button allows the user to delete a previously saved power scheme. It is greyed out, indicating that the currently selected scheme ("Home/Office Desk") cannot be deleted.
* **Settings for Home/Office Desk power scheme:** This section lists four power management options, each with a corresponding dropdown menu to adjust the timing:
    * **Turn off monitor:** Currently set to "After 20 mins."
    * **Turn off hard disks:** Currently set to "Never."
    * **System standby:** Currently set to "Never."
    * **System hibernates:** Currently set to "Never."
* **OK button:**  This button applies the current power scheme settings and closes the window.
* **Cancel button:** This button discards any changes made to the power scheme settings and closes the window.
* **Apply button:** This button applies the current power scheme settings without closing the window.

The mouse cursor is hovering over the "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu, indicating that this setting can be adjusted.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window, with the "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu expanded, revealing a list of time intervals. 

Content Changes:
- The "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu is now expanded, displaying options: "After 25 mins", "After 30 mins", "After 45 mins", "After 1 hour", "After 2 hours", "After 3 hours", "After 4 hours", "After 5 hours", and "Never".

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu expanded, displaying a list of time intervals. 

Content Changes:
- The "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu is now expanded, revealing options ranging from "After 3 mins" to "Never".

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu expanded, displaying a list of time intervals. 

Content Changes:

- The "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu is now expanded, revealing a list of time intervals ranging from "After 1 min" to "Never".

The "Power Options Properties" window is open and active, displaying the "Power Schemes" tab. The "Home/Office Desk" power scheme is currently selected in the "Power schemes" dropdown menu. 

Below, the "Settings for Home/Office Desk power scheme" section lists four power-saving options: "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates". Each option has a dropdown menu to define the time after which the action will be performed.  The "System hibernates" dropdown menu is expanded, displaying a list of time intervals ranging from "After 1 min" to "After 5 hours", with "Never" being the currently selected and highlighted option.

The "Power Options Properties" window remains open, and the "Power Schemes" tab is still active. 

Content Changes:

- The "Power schemes" dropdown menu now displays "Home/Office Desk" instead of "Never". 
- All four power-saving options ("Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates") now have their dropdown menus set to "Never". Notably, the "System hibernates" dropdown is no longer expanded.

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. 

The "Power Schemes" tab is active, featuring the following elements:

* **Power schemes:** A dropdown menu currently displaying "Home/Office Desk". This menu allows users to select from pre-defined power schemes or those created by the user.
* **Save As...**: A button enabling users to save the current power settings as a new, custom scheme. 
* **Delete**: A button to delete a user-created power scheme. This button is greyed out, indicating no custom schemes are currently selected.

Below, the "Settings for Home/Office Desk power scheme" section lists power-saving options:

* **Turn off monitor:**, **Turn off hard disks:**, **System standby:**, and **System hibernates:** Each option is paired with a dropdown menu currently set to "Never". These settings control the time delay before the monitor, hard drive, system standby, and system hibernation activate. 

At the bottom of the window, three standard buttons are visible:

* **OK**: Closes the window and applies any changes made to the power settings.
* **Cancel**: Closes the window without saving any changes.
* **Apply**: Immediately applies any changes made to the power settings without closing the window.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window, specifically the "Power Schemes" tab. 

Content Changes:

- The "Power schemes" dropdown menu now displays "Home/Office Desk" as the selected option. The dropdown menu is expanded, revealing three available power schemes: "Home/Office Desk", "Always On", and "Minimal Power Management". "Max Battery" is no longer present as a power scheme option.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. The "Power Schemes" tab is active. The "Power schemes" dropdown menu now displays "Home/Office Desk" as selected, with other options visible in the dropdown list: "Presentation", "Always On", "Minimal Power Management", and "Max Battery".  The "Settings for Home/Office Desk power scheme" section remains unchanged, with all dropdown menus for "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates" still set to "Never".

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window, specifically the "Power Schemes" tab. 

Content Changes:

- The "Power schemes" dropdown menu now displays "Always On".

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. 

The "Power Schemes" tab is active, presenting a dropdown menu labeled "Power schemes" with the "Always On" option currently selected. This menu allows users to choose from pre-configured power plans or custom ones. 

Below, a list of power-saving settings appears, each with a corresponding dropdown menu to define its behavior:

* **Turn off monitor:**  Currently set to "Never". This option controls the time delay before the monitor enters power-saving mode. 
* **Turn off hard disks:** Currently set to "Never". This option controls the time delay before the hard drive enters power-saving mode.
* **System standby:** Currently set to "Never". This option controls the time delay before the system enters standby mode.
* **System hibernates:** Currently set to "Never". This option controls the time delay before the system enters hibernation mode.

At the bottom of the window, three buttons are visible:

* **OK:**  Clicking this button applies any changes made within the "Power Options Properties" window and closes the window.
* **Cancel:** Clicking this button discards any changes made and closes the window.
* **Apply:** Clicking this button applies any changes made within the "Power Options Properties" window without closing it.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Power Schemes" tab active. The "Always On" power scheme is selected in the dropdown menu. 

The following settings within "Power Schemes" are all set to "Never":
- Turn off monitor
- Turn off hard disks
- System standby
- System hibernates

Two new buttons, "Save As.." and "Delete", are now visible to the right of the "Power schemes" dropdown menu.

The "Power Options Properties" window is open and active, with the "Power Schemes" tab in view. The "Always On" power scheme is currently selected from the "Power schemes" dropdown menu. This scheme is designed to keep the computer continuously powered on, preventing automatic power-saving actions.

Within the "Settings for Always On power scheme" section, four distinct power management options are presented, each with a corresponding dropdown menu to adjust its setting: 

* **Turn off monitor:** This option controls the automatic deactivation of the monitor. It is currently set to "After 20 mins."
* **Turn off hard disks:** This option controls the automatic powering down of the hard disks. It is currently set to "Never".
* **System standby:** This option controls when the computer enters a low-power standby mode. It is currently set to "Never."
* **System hibernates:** This option controls when the computer enters hibernation, saving the system state to the hard drive. It is currently set to "Never." 

At the bottom of the window, three buttons offer ways to manage the power scheme settings:

* **OK:** Clicking this button applies any changes made to the power scheme settings and closes the window.
* **Cancel:** Clicking this button discards any changes made to the power scheme settings and closes the window.
* **Apply:** Clicking this button immediately applies any changes made to the power scheme settings without closing the window.

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. The "Always On" power scheme is currently selected in the "Power schemes" dropdown menu. This scheme is designed to keep the computer running at all times without triggering power-saving modes. 

Under the "Settings for Always On power scheme" section, four options are presented, each with a corresponding dropdown menu to adjust the timing:

* **Turn off monitor:** This option determines the duration of inactivity before the monitor enters power-saving mode. Currently, it is set to "After 20 mins".
* **Turn off hard disks:** This option controls the timer for hard disk inactivity before they enter power-saving mode. It is currently set to "Never".
* **System standby:** This option sets the delay before the system enters standby mode. It is currently set to "Never".
* **System hibernates:** This option determines the time after which the system will hibernate. It is also currently set to "Never".

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu expanded, displaying the available time options. 

Content Changes:
- The "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu is now expanded, revealing options such as "After 15 mins," "After 20 mins," "After 25 mins," and more.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu expanded, displaying a list of time interval options: "After 3 mins", "After 5 mins", "After 10 mins", "After 15 mins", "After 20 mins" (currently selected), "After 30 mins", "After 45 mins", "After 1 hour", "After 2 hours", "After 3 hours", "After 4 hours", "After 5 hours", and "Never".

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Turn off monitor" dropdown menu expanded, revealing a list of time intervals ranging from "After 1 min" to "Never". 

The "Turn off monitor" option, previously set to "After 20 mins", is now highlighted, indicating the user has clicked on this dropdown menu.

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically focused on configuring the "Always On" power scheme. 

The "Power schemes" dropdown menu is open, displaying "Always On" as the currently selected scheme. This menu allows users to choose from predefined power plans or custom ones. 

Below, the "Settings for Always On power scheme" section lists four power-saving options: "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates". Each option has a dropdown menu next to it, currently displaying a range of time intervals and the option "Never". The mouse cursor is hovering over the "Never" option within the "System hibernates" dropdown menu, indicating the user's current selection. 

Three buttons are visible to the right of the power scheme selection: "Save As...", "Delete", and (partially obscured) "Help". The "Save As..." button allows users to save the current settings as a new power scheme, while "Delete" removes the selected scheme.

The screenshot shows the "Power Options Properties" window with the "Always On" power scheme selected. All four power-saving options: "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates" are set to "Never". 

The "Power schemes" dropdown menu is no longer open. 

The mouse cursor is not visible in this screenshot.

The screenshot displays the "Power Options Properties" window in Windows XP. 

The "Power Schemes" tab is active, and the "Always On" power scheme is selected in the dropdown menu. This scheme is designed to maximize system performance by preventing power-saving features from activating.

Below, the "Settings for Always On power scheme" section lists four system power states: "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates". Each state has a corresponding dropdown menu, currently set to "Never". This configuration ensures that none of the power-saving features will activate automatically.

At the bottom of the window are three buttons: "OK", "Cancel", and "Apply".  The "Cancel" button is highlighted, indicating it was the most recent action taken with the mouse.
The "Power Options Properties" window remains open. The "Cancel" button is no longer highlighted. The mouse cursor now hovers over the "OK" button.

Missing UI Elements: 
- The "Power Options Properties" window is no longer present.

New UI Elements:
- The "Display Properties" window is now visible, displaying a blank white area on the right side.

The screenshot shows the "Appearance and Themes" window open in the foreground. The "Display Properties" window, previously described with specific settings in the "Power Options Properties" section, is no longer present.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Power Options Properties" window is not present. 

Content Changes:
- The "Power Schemes" tab, mentioned in the initial description, is not visible in the screenshot.
- The dropdown menus for "Turn off monitor", "Turn off hard disks", "System standby", and "System hibernates" are not present.
- The "OK", "Cancel", and "Apply" buttons are not visible.

New UI Elements:
- The "Display Properties" window is visible, with the "Screen Saver" tab active.
- A preview of a blank screen with the text "panel icon" is displayed. 
- A dropdown menu labeled "Screen saver" is set to "[None]".
- A "Power" button is located at the bottom of the window.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, with the "Screen Saver" tab active. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Power Options Properties" window is no longer present. 

Content Changes:
- The previously highlighted "Cancel" button in the "Power Options Properties" window is no longer highlighted.

The screenshot displays the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. 

The user has selected "None" from the "Screen saver" dropdown menu, disabling the screen saver function. 

The "Wait" field and its associated options ("minutes", "On resume, password protect") are grayed out, indicating their inactivity due to the disabled screen saver. 

The "Monitor power" section provides a brief instruction: "To adjust monitor power settings and save energy, click Power." This section guides the user towards further power management options. 

At the bottom of the window, several buttons are visible:
 - "OK": This button confirms the current settings and closes the window.  
 - "Cancel": This button discards any changes made and closes the window. 
 - "Apply": This button applies any changes made without closing the window. 

The mouse cursor hovers over the "OK" button, indicating the user's next action will be to confirm the current settings and close the "Display Properties" window.

The screenshot shows the "Display Properties" window in Windows XP, specifically the "Screen Saver" tab. The "Screen saver" dropdown menu shows "None" selected. The "Wait" field and the "On resume, password protect" checkbox are grayed out. The mouse cursor is hovering over the "OK" button.

The screenshot shows the "Appearance and Themes" window open within the Windows XP Control Panel. 

Missing UI Elements:
- The "Display Properties" window is no longer present.

The screenshot displays the "Appearance and Themes" window within the Windows XP Control Panel. The window presents two main sections:

**1. "See Also" and "Troubleshooters" (Left Panel):** This section provides quick links to related system tasks:

   - **"See Also":** Offers access to settings for "Fonts," "Mouse Pointers," "High Contrast," and "User Account Picture."
   - **"Troubleshooters":** Provides troubleshooting options for "Display" and "Sound" related issues.

**2. "Pick a task..." and Control Panel Icons (Right Panel):** This section offers direct access to common appearance and theme customization options:

   - **"Pick a task...":** Lists several actions: "Change the computer's theme," "Change the desktop background," "Choose a screen saver," and "Change the screen resolution." Each action, when clicked, would lead to its respective settings window.
   - **Control Panel Icons:** Displays two additional Control Panel icons:
      - **"Display":** Clicking this icon would open the "Display Properties" window.
      - **"Folder Options":** Clicking this icon would open the "Folder Options" window.
